police as a force for good, to a force.

Paradoxically, they are deeply engaged in Orwellian Doublespeak as they 
re-brand themselves as the Police 'Service' - trying to shake off the 
Police 'Force' label they gave themselves for centuries. What makes this

The numbers about mean that Black people ,per population numbers, are 
approximately 3 times more likely (person to person) to commit a violent 
crime.  That said... of course there are whites committing crimes.  Every 
race has some bad seeds and I think any rational person would admit that.

According to the FBI, in 2011, white people committed about 6.58 million 
crimes; Blacks committed 2.7 million.  White people were arrested more 
often than any other race for violent crimes.  Whites account for 60% of 
all violent crime arrest in America.

White people make up about 80% of the American population, according to the 
United States Census. And Black people account for about 13%.  Yet, 
according to the same FBI table, Blacks committed 28.4% of the crimes and 
whites 69.2%. This makes our Black part of the  “crime pie” larger than our 
slice of the population pie- actually more than double.

 This doesn’t mean each Black Person is committing two crimes each. It 
means that the pool for crimes is much smaller than the pool for our 
population. And so when one person commits a crime they account for a small 
number in the population, but a bigger number contributing to the crime 
statistic.

Because Black People account for more of the crime statistic than we do the 
population, we contribute a “disproportionate” amount, meaning our pie 
slices are uneven. Conversely, white rates are a little more even. 80% of 
the population, versus a little more than 69% of crime.

It appears that the evidence to support a criminal indictment of the 
subject officer in this matter did not surpass the 'reasonable doubt' 
threshold. Therefore the Grand Jury did the proper thing.

Notwithstanding, the officer appears to be civilly liable here for 
contributing to and procuring the very circumstances that led to the use of 
lethal force. This means the officer was negligent and substantially more 
in-the-wrong than the driver.

Clearly, the officer attempted to make a traffic stop by utilizing his body 
and when this failed he elected to use deadly force.

The officer shot at least 4 times through the driver's side of the 
windshield. The bullet holes in the glass suggest to me he was in front of 
the motor vehicle while shooting and not out of harms way to left side of 
the car, and that he had maintained sufficient balance during the 
altercation to pull his gun and shoot.

The liability for the shooting and therefore the negligent actions or 
inactions in this case, rest entirely on the officer.

In this analysis one needs to offset some of the officer's civil liability 
by taking into account the actions or inactions of the driver.

There is no evidence that the driver received and understood the demands to 
stop made by the officer. I see no evidence that suggests she was 
attempting to evade. Clearly, the officer was able to get in front of her 
car while he was on foot.

The fact that it was established after the occurrence that the female 
driver was impaired is material but it would be more significant if the 
officer had some reasonable and probable grounds to believe she was PRIOR 
to initiating the traffic stop. The officer made no assessment of the 
driver or her driving pattern at any time prior to the use of lethal force.

My sense is I would find it difficult to find the driver more than 25% per 
cent responsible for what occurred. This means, I would be compelled to 
find the officer at least 75% liable.

Had the officer acted in a manner that was consistent with his training and 
common sense, this tragedy would not have occurred. As a consequence of the 
negligent conduct of the officer, the driver is dead and he is civilly 
liable.﻿
